journal-meta.journal-title: Proceedings of the Institution of Mechanical Engineers, Part K: Journal of Multi-body Dynamics

title-group.article-title: The impact of non-linear stretching on the dynamic stability of a uniformly loaded, thin, warped, rotating, circular disk

article-meta.aff: College of Engineering, Architecture, and Computer Sciences, Howard University, Washington, DC, USA

author-notes.corresp: Grant M Warner, College of Engineering, Architecture, and Computer Sciences, Howard University, Washington, DC 20059, USA. Email: g_warner@howard.edu

abstract.p: This article analyzes the dynamic stability of pre-warped, rotating circular disks. Simulation is used to determine asymmetric equilibria and corresponding stability maps for varying load and disk rotation. Experimental results corroborated the presence of a rotating, asymmetric equilibrium for low speeds. At higher speeds, aerodynamically excited vibration made it impossible to identify steady equilibria. However, the nature of the aerodynamic excitation and its onset were dramatically affected by the presence of uniform loading on the disk. In addition, at high rotation speeds, the disk appears to have a steady equilibrium rotation at one quarter of the rotation speed of the disk.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: This article considers the dynamic stability of pre-warped, rotating circular disks loaded by a uniform force of sufficient magnitude that the in-plane stretching of the disk caused by transverse loading affects disk stability. This can occur, for instance, in flexible disks loaded by gravity.

Figure 1 shows a contour plot of an experimentally measured, static, non-rotating deflection of a flexible Mylar disk, removed from its housing, and bending under gravity. In the plot, the deflection has been normalized by disk thickness (0.05 mm; see Table 1 for dimensional parameters of typical rotating disk devices). The measured deflection is clearly not axisymmetric, as it would be if the disk were perfect and the behavior were linear; instead, it folds smoothly across a horizontal diameter, with a maximum edge deflection of about 20 disk thicknesses. Large developable deflections such as these are frequently observed in the bending of thin plates, and a boundary layer solution giving an intuitive understanding of this behavior has been known for decades.1,2 A number of researchers have investigated the non-linear behavior of thin plates and disks including Hamidzadeh and Luo.3–6 Figure 1.
Contour plot of a static flexible disk deflection under gravity loading. Contours are drawn in units of disk thickness (0.05 mm). Table 1.
Operational parameters for typical rotating disk devices.
Floppy disk Zip disk Hard disk drive Circular saw
Outer radius, Ro (mm) 43 43 65 152
Inner radius, Ri (mm) 12.5 12.5 19.5 67
Thickness, H (mm) 0.05 0.05 0.8 1.5
Rotation speed, Ω* (r/min) 720 2800 10,000 4400
Density, ρ (kg/m3) 1300 1300 2800 7800
Young’s modulus, E (GPa) 4 4 72 207
Poisson's ratio, ν 0.3 0.3 0.3 0.3
Clamping ratio, κ 0.291 0.291 0.300 0.441
Dimensionless rotation speed, Ω 5.25 20.4 3.60 4.55
Gravity loading, Γ 952 952 0.145 0.64

Nevertheless, to the author’s knowledge, many relevant engineering questions concerning the dynamic stability of this system have not been previously investigated: what is the critical load at which the linear, axisymmetric solution becomes unstable, and how does that critical load change with the rotation speed of the disk; apart from rigid body rotations of the solution shown in Figure 1, are there other equilibrium solutions and are they stable; how do perturbations in the initial disk shape (pre-warp) and rotational eccentricity affect stability? The answers to these questions demarcate different stability regions, a knowledge of which can be useful in the design and operation of flexible rotating disk devices. For example, it is certainly interesting and it may be important to know whether the folded equilibrium shown in Figure 1 disappears or persists when the disk is spun at operational speed. Design features, which impact system stability, could increase the operation speed of the device, and allow for faster data access or higher throughput for disk drive and saw mill applications, respectively.

Linear analysis of the deflection of very thin, rotating disks indicates that they are particularly susceptible to large deflections even for very small stationary loads.3,7,8 The possibility of nonlinear deflection provides an opportunity to design the operational disk deflection so as to enhance disk stability, an opportunity not present in the linear case.

In the literature on the stability of rotating disk devices, stability is characterized by an interaction between the rotating disk and a stationary load or stiffness (cutting and guide forces in circular saws; read/write head interactions and hydrodynamic forces for computer memory disks). In the vast majority of cases, the disk is assumed to be axisymmetric; this is usually realistic and has the computational advantage that the governing equations written in the stationary frame of reference are autonomous in time. Natural frequency and stability calculations therefore reduce to matrix eigenvalue problems. This approach is used, for example, by Iwan and Moeller9 to determine the natural frequencies and critical speeds of axisymmetric circular disks loaded by a concentrated, stationary stiffness. Even when the disk is not axisymmetric, the disk is often modeled using averaged, axisymmetric properties in order to simplify analysis.10–13

When axisymmetry of the disk cannot be assumed, the equations of motion in the rotating frame of reference only remain autonomous in time when the stationary load or stiffness is axisymmetric. For asymmetric loads and stiffnesses, the equations of motion become periodic in time and instability arises through parametric excitation. For example, Yu and Mote14 and Shen and Mote15 determine the boundaries of parametrically excited instability for a rotating circular disk with peripheral slots similar to those found in industrial circular saws. While such analyses are straightforward, they are computationally expensive, and the resulting stability results are not as widely applicable as those for axisymmetric disks.

In the present study, asymmetric disk equilibria with uniform, axisymmetric loading (e.g. gravity) are considered. The equations of motion remain autonomous in the rotating frame of reference and stability reduces to the solution of a self-adjoint eigenvalue problem. This allows computational resources to be concentrated on determining non-linear equilibria. The disk is modeled using the von Karman thin plate equations. A few simple analytic solutions are known to these equations,2 and in special cases involving either axisymmety16 or small perturbations,17,18 numerical solutions are relatively easy to obtain. This is not the case for the rotating disk geometry and highly asymmetric solutions considered here. This, therefore, requires a two dimensional numerical discretization of the governing equations followed by use of a multidimensional root finding routine to determine numerical solutions. Previous research using numerical solutions of these equations have shown reasonable agreement with experimental results,19 but the numerical results have not been entirely satisfactory. The resulting stability boundaries have exhibited numerical ‘noise’, resulting in non-smooth stability boundaries.

In order to reduce the computational expense of problem, previous researchers have often employed only a few polynomial or trigonometric trial functions together with either Galerkin’s method or a variational method based on the system energy.2,19–22 The principle advantage of these methods is the fact that solutions are represented by relatively few degrees of freedom, leading to an inexpensive numerical search for unknown equilibria. The principle disadvantage of these methods is the solution uncertainty. The solutions found are only those realizable by the trial functions selected, and, in general, the residuals are non-zero, often by a substantial amount.

Ideally, one wants an approximate solution that is highly accurate, has as few degrees of freedom as possible, and does not assume any a priori knowledge about the solution (as is required to select appropriate trial functions using Galerkin’s or variational methods). Spectral collocation appears to be such a method.23 The method converges very rapidly for smooth functions such as those sought here, requires less degrees of freedom than finite difference methods, and does not assume any a priori solution information.

In the present study, the solution is discretized using spectral collocation.24 This approach has the advantage that the discretization errors are very small for relatively low numbers (i.e. feasible) of degrees of freedom. The algorithm employed selects a small relative error tolerance a priori (10−8) and requires that all numerical solutions have errors less than this tolerance at all spectral nodes. This ensures that the numerical results are accurate and not numerical artifacts even though both convergence and numerical noise remain problematic.

The article is formatted as follows. Section ‘Problem formulation’ gives the mathematical formulation of the von Karmans thin plate equations. Section ‘Axisymmetric equilibria’ computes the axisymmetric solutions and their stability. Section ‘Asymmetric solutions’ computes asymmetric equilibria and their solutions for perfect disks, and disks with initial pre-warp. The section following it describes experimental results aimed at corroborating the stability finds. Last of the sections present discussion and conclusions.

sec.title: Problem formulation
sec.p: A circular disk, clamped at inner radius Ri and free at outer radius R0 spins about a transverse axis at a constant angular speed Ω*. The disk is of constant thickness H, density ρ, Young’s modulus E, and Poisson’s ratio ν. Polar coordinates are fixed to the disk in the rotating frame of reference (R,θ) with the center of the disk at the origin. Pertinent dimensional variables include time T, transverse displacement W (measured from the R - θ plane), in-plane, radial and circumferential displacements U and V, in-plane radial, hoop, and shear stresses σr*, σθ*, and τrθ*, and gravitational acceleration g.

The goal is to investigate two asymmetric imperfections on the stability of this system. First, the center of rotation is located at R = e′, θ = θe, where e′ ≪ Ro. And second, the unloaded and unclamped disk assumes the warped, stress-free, initial deformation W~.

Variables are rendered dimensionless as follows (1)r=R/Ro e=e'/Ro t=TD/ρHRo4w=W/H w~=W~/Hu=12URo/H2v=12VRo/H2σr=σr*HRo2/D σθ=σθ*HRo2/D τrθ=τrθ*HRo2/D where D=EH3/12(1-ν2). Three dimensionless parameters are defined:
The clamping ratio (2)k=Ri/Ro
The gravity loading magnitude (3)Γ=ρgRo4/D
And the dimensionless rotation speed (4)Ω=Ω*ρHRo4/D
The plate is modeled using von Karman plate theory.2 The in-plane, polar strains are given by (5)ɛr=u,r+6(w,r2-w~,r2)ɛθ=u/r+ν,θ/r+6(w,θ2-w~,θ2)/r2γrθ=u,θ/r+ν,r-ν/r+12(w,rw,θ-w~,rw~,θ)/r
Under conditions of plane stress, the in-plane stresses are (6)σr=ɛr+νɛθ σθ=ɛθ+νɛr τrθ=(1-ν)γrθ/2
The in-plane, radial and circumferential equilibrium equations are (7)σr,r+τrθ,θ/r+(σr-σq)/r=-Ω2[r-ecos(θ-θe)] (8)σθ,θ/r+τrθ,ρ+2τrθ/r=-Ω2esin(θ-θe)
The equation of transverse equilibrium is (9)w,tt=Γ-∇4(w-w~)+(rσrw,r+τrθw,θ),r/r +(τrθw,r+σθw,θ/r),θ/r
At the clamped edge, r = κ, the boundary conditions are (10)u=v=w=w,r=0
At the free edge, r=1, the traction, moment and shear vanish (11)σr=τrθ=0 w,rr+ν(w,r/r+w,θθ/r2)=w~,rr+ν(w~,r/r+w~,θθ/r2)(∇4w),r+(1-ν)(w,rθθ-w,θθ/r)/r2 =(∇4w~),r+(1-ν)(w~,rθθ-w~,θθ/r)/r2

The potential energy associated with any solution is given by the integral over the disk of the strain energy due to bending plus the in-plane strain energy minus the work done by the external forces (12)U=∫-Γ(w-w~)-112Ω2[r-ecos(θ-θe)]u -112Ω2esin(θ-θe)υ+124(σrɛr+σθɛθ+τrθγrθ) +12(∇2(w-w~))2-(1-ν)(w,rr-w~,rr) ×((w,r-w~,r)r+(w,θθ-w~,θθ)r2) +(1-n)[((w,r-w~,r)r),r]2dA

sec.title: Axisymmetric equilibria
sec.p: The search for axisymmetric equilibria begins with w~=e=0 w~=e=0, i.e. no warping or rotational eccentricity. The axisymmetric equilibria and their stability are determined by the substitutions (13)u=u0(r)+ɛu1(r)cos(nθ)eλtv=ɛv1(r)sin(nθ)eλtw=w0(r)+ɛwr(r)cos(nθ)eλt where ε is an arbitrary small parameter and n is an integer: equilibrium is determined with ε = 0; stability of the equilibrium is determined by linearizing the governing equations about the equilibrium (i.e. taking those terms in the governing equations of order ε) and determining the eigenvalues λ2 associated with that problem. (The factor ε does not appear in the resulting problem and is never specified.) Since the resulting eigenvalue problem for λ2 is self-adjoint, only real values of λ2 are possible; the system is unstable when max(λ2) > 0.

Under equation (13), the equilibrium and stability equations reduce to coupled ordinary differential equations in r. The most direct solution method is a shooting procedure in which the unknown initial conditions at r = κ are guessed and then systematically varied until the errors in the boundary conditions at r = 1 that occur when the ordinary differential equations are numerically integrated to r = 1 vanish.

Figure 2 shows the radial deflection u and the transverse deflection w as functions of r for the axisymmetric solution for Ω = 0, 5, 10, 15, 20, and 25 for Γ = 1250; κ = 0.291, ν = 0.3. With the normalization adopted, u is approximately one to two orders of magnitude greater than w. With no rotation, u is strongly negative while w is positive. As Ω increases, the centrifugal forces on the disk increase the magnitude of u until for Ω > 20 it is positive for all values of r; correspondingly, the values of w decrease as it is stretched by rotational forces. Figure 2.
Axisymmetric equilibrium solutions for different values of Ω. Γ = 1250; κ = 0.291; ν = 0.3.

Figure 3 shows the stability curves for various values of n plotting the critical buckling load Γcrit as a function of Ω for the ranges 0≤Ω≤25; κ = 0.291, ν = 0.3. The axisymmetric equilibria become unstable when Γ exceeds 116 for Ω = 0, 235 for Ω = 5, 709 for Ω = 10, and 1658 when Ω = 15. The number of nodal diameters in the unstable mode, which is indicated by n, ranges from 3 to 5 for the data shown. Modes with n = 0 or 1 are never unstable. Steady equilibria are difficult to obtain numerical for Γ > 3000 or so; this region lies at the end of the stability curves. Axisymmetric equilibria lying below all of these curves are stable; axisymmetric equilibria lying above any of these curves are unstable. Figure 3.
Buckling load of the axisymmetric equilibrium for different numbers of nodal diameters n in the buckling mode. Modes n = 0 and n = 1 are always stable. κ = 0.291; ν = 0.3. Results based on the shooting method.

sec.title: Numerical solution procedure
sec.p: The shooting method described in the previous section is fast and accurate, but only applicable to axisymmetric equilibria. For asymmetric equilibria such as those shown in Figure 1, a more general numerical method is required. Spectral collocation is used in this work.23

A tensor product grid of collocations points is generated using NQ equally spaced points in the circumferential direction and NR Chebyshev–Lobatto collocation points including two false points, one less than r = κ, the other greater than r = 1, in the radial direction. The value of w is sought at each of these NQ X NR collocation points. The nodes are partitioned into two sets: the false nodes included the inner most and outer most pairs of annular rings of nodes; all other nodes are considered free nodes. Initial values for w for the free NQ X (NR – 4) collocation nodes are guessed. The values of w at each of the false nodes are determined by solving the four plate boundary conditions (10) and (11). With a full representation of w determined, corresponding nodal values of u and v are determined by solving the linear equations derived from (7) and (8) together with the boundary conditions. With nodal values of u, v, and w known, the error in equation (9) is computed at each free nodal point. A multidimensional root finder using Newton’s method adjusted the initial guess of w at each of the free nodes until the error in equation (9) was less than a pre-set tolerance at each node. For the results reported here, the tolerance was 10−8.

In all cases, to optimize computation time, the solution was assumed to have quadrilateral symmetry, i.e. symmetric u and w and antisymmetric v about θ = 0 and θ = π/2. Hence, the total number of degrees of freedom in the nonlinear search was NQ X (NR – 4)/4. Typically NQ = 36 and NR = 20, giving a total of 144 degrees of freedom in the equilibrium search.

The stability of each equilibrium was determined by linearizing equations (7) to (9) while assuming a separable time dependence eλt. The first order perturbations for u and v were solved in terms of the first order perturbation of w. These were then substituted into the self-adjoint eigenvalue problem given by equation (9). The boundary conditions for w were used in the eigenvalue problem for the false nodes. No symmetry conditions were assumed in the perturbation problem; hence the stability problem led to a quadratic eigenvalue problem of order NQ X NR, which equals 720 for NQ = 36 and NR = 20.

sec.title: Axisymmetric results
sec.p: The axisymmetric results were repeated using the spectral collocation scheme. The stability boundary shown in Figure 2 was reproduced with less than 3% error with a discretization of NQ = 12 and NR = 14. Initial guesses of w = 0 at all nodes always lead to the axisymmetric solution even though only quadrilateral symmetry was assumed.

sec.title: Asymmetric results with no warping or rotational eccentricity
sec.p: There appears to be no systematic method for searching for asymmetric equilibria. In fact, using the tolerance of 10−8, asymmetric equilibria are extremely difficult to find, and their region of convergence is small.

After extensive numerical testing, the following brute force search method was adopted in order to find asymmetric equilibria. Initial guesses of the deflection were derived from a linear combination of trial functions of the form (14)w=∑m=02∑n=02cmn(r-κ)m+2cos(2nθ) where the coefficients cmn were varied on a regularly spaced grid between −1 and 1. This method had a success rate of finding asymmetric equilibria of approximately 1–2% using a discretization of NQ = 36 and NR = 20.

Figure 4 shows four different equilibria for Γ = 500, Ω = 0, κ = 0.291, and ν = 0.3. Along with each equilibrium, the most unstable eigenvalue (max(λ2)) and the potential energy U are listed. The contours have been smoothed using bicubic spline interpolation so that the underlying discretization is not apparent. The four equilibria can be categorized by the number of nodal ridges in the solution. Solution #0 is the axisymmetric solution, which is unstable (λ2 = 820) and has no nodal ridges. Solution #1 has one nodal ridge, shown along the θ = π/2 axis. This is the only stable mode discovered. The value of λ2 = 0.275 was taken to be essentially zero. Note that all asymmetric equilibria must possess vanishing eigenvalues corresponding to rigid body rotation of the solution. Hence stability for these equilibria is determined by either: max(λ2) = 0, stable; or max(λ2) > 0, unstable. In this case the stability is corroborated by the fact that this solution has the lowest potential energy among the four solutions found. Solution #2 has two nodal ridges along the θ = 0 and θ = π/2 axes and is unstable. Solution #3 has three nodal ridges along θ = π/4, θ = π/2, and θ = 3π/4 axes, and is unstable. Figure 4.
Contour plots of four prototypical equilibrium deflections w(r,θ) with quadrilateral symmetry. Γ = 500; Ω = 0; κ = 0.291; ν = 0.3. NQ = 36; NR = 20. Contours have been smoothed using cubic spline interpolation. Contours drawn every 0.5 units.

Figure 5 shows the potential energy U and max(λ2) for each of the four solutions of Figure 4 as the loading Γ is varied over two orders of magnitude from 10 to 1000. Ω = 0. In the figure, the cube root of max(λ2) is shown in order visually separate and distinguish the behavior of each solution. This graph illustrates several important properties of the equilibrium solutions. First, each of the three asymmetric solutions bifurcate smoothly from the axisymmetric solution at different locations above the critical value of Γ(116) at which the axisymmetric solution is unstable. Second, in each case, the potential energy of the bifurcated solution is less than the axisymmetric solution. Third, the only stable asymmetric solution found is Solution #1, which is only stable for Γ > 500 or so. Fourth, for 116 < Γ < 500, no stable solutions to the problem were located. This illustrates the limitations of the brute force numerical method in that not all solutions are found. Fifth, Solution #3 could not be located for Γ > 540. These results indicate that the same numerical noise difficulties affecting previous researchers also affect the current results. As shown in Figure 6, eccentricity has a minimal effect on the buckling load. Large differentiation did not occur until eccentricities of 10% and 20% were introduced, which is unlikely in practice. Figure 5.
Comparison of U and max(λ2) for four prototypical solutions. Cube root taken to visually separate solutions. Ω = 0; κ = 0.291; ν = 0.3. Solution #3 is lost for Γ > 450. Figure 6.
Buckling load vs. rotation speed for eccentric rotation. κ = 0.291; ν = 0.3.

sec.title: Pre-warp
sec.p:
Figure 7 illustrates the effect of a pre-warp of the form w~=ar2cos2θ, corresponding to a constant curvature parallel the θ = π/2 axis. Results for a = −2.0, −1.5, −1.0, −0.5, 0, 0.5, 1.0, and 2.0 are shown. The most conspicuous result from the graph is that at high speeds all disk behavior effectively mirrors the results of an unwarped disk. In particular, at the operating range of most flexible disks, Ω = 20, prewarp is not a factor with respect to the buckling load. At lower speeds however, prewarp does have a range of effects. Larger prewarps have larger effects on the buckling load. Also, with one exception, negative warping (a < 0) has the effect of increasing the buckling load, while positive warping (a > 0) decreases the buckling load. Figure 7.
Buckling load vs. rotation speed for warping w~=ar2cos2θ. κ = 0.291; ν = 0.3.

Small prewarps (a = 0.5, a = −0.5) had little effect on the buckling load. Consistent with the general trend, positive warping slightly decreased the buckling load while negative warping slightly increased the buckling load. For Ω > 5 there is little significant difference between the prewarped and unwarped disk.

Larger prewarps (a = −1.5, a = −1, a = 1) demonstrate the same trends. Positive warping lowers the buckling load in the region Ω < 4 by a factor of 4. By Ω = 7 there is no significant difference between its results and those of an unwarped disk. Likewise, for large negative prewarpthere is a significant effect on the buckling load. In the region Ω < 10 negative prewarp increases the buckling load by as much as an order of magnitude.

The largest initial curvatures (a = −2 and 2) significantly decrease the buckling load for Ω < 15. Above Ω = 15 the centrifugal forces are sufficient such that the buckling load is essentially the same as for an unwarped disk. Below Ω = 15, the critical load is approximately an order of magnitude less than that of an unwarped disk. Unlike for smaller curvatures, large negative curvatures didn’t increase the buckling load relative to the unwarped disk. However, it did increase the buckling load relative to the positive prewarp.

sec.title: Experimental results
sec.p: A set of experiments were performed to corroborate the numerical results presented here. There are three primary experimental difficulties: first, since the asymmetric solutions rotate with the disk, their presence can only be inferred from stationary measurements. Second, aerodynamic excitation is significant. And third, since the stability transitions derive from smooth bifurcations, transitions from axisymmetric to asymmetric equilibria occur continuously without any obvious experimentally measurable indication. While experimental design was able to address the first of these problems, the second and third difficulties prevented direct comparisons with the numerical results.

The magnetic clamp and bearing of a disk drive were removed and attached to a rigid frame. A DC motor was also attached to the frame and connected to the flexible disk clamp/bearing by a belt drive. Computer control of the DC motor allowed variable disk rotation from 0 to 2800 r/min (Ω = 20.4, the normal operating range for flexible disks. Flexible, magnetic polymer disks were removed from their housings and mounted on the magnetic clamp/bearing. In the set-up, there was a clearance of 8 mm between a flat aluminum plate and the bottom surface of the disk. While this is 160 times the thickness of the disk, it is still close enough to influence the airflow around the disk. There were no obstructions above the top surface of the disk.

Two Philtec Photonic displacement sensors with a sensitivity of 0.548 × 10−3 m/V and 1.39 m/V respectively were positioned above the magnetic polymer disk at a radius of 38 mm on the disk (r = 0.826) and approximately 90° apart. These non-contact sensors measured the transverse position of the disk. The flexible disk was spun from 133 to 2800 r/min in increments of approximately 140 r/min. At each fixed speed, the system was allowed to settle to equilibrium for 2 s, and then displacement measurements were taken with both sensors. A variable sample rate tied to the motor input voltage, V, was used to keep the number of disk rotations per measurement period approximately equal. For these results, the sample rate (in Hz) was 3000 times the voltage (in volts). The input voltage varied between 0.25 and 5.0 V.

The correlation coefficient between the measurements of the two probes at various lags was computed. If the disk possesses an asymmetric equilibrium rotating with the disk, then the correlation coefficient is maximized when the lag between the data sets corresponds to the time required for a point on the disk to rotate from one probe to the other. This procedure was inverted by finding the lag that maximized the correlation coefficient and then computing the angle rotated by the disk in the time interval corresponding to the lag. For each experiment, a set of seven data measurements were performed. This allowed reporting of average and standard deviations on the maximum correlation coefficient and the disk rotation angle corresponding to the maximum correlation lag.

Figure 8 shows the maximum correlation coefficient and corresponding lag as a function of rotation speed for a horizontal disk (Γ = 1250). The results indicate three distinct speed regions. For Ω* < = 1250 r/min (Ω = 9.1), the maximum correlation coefficient is large (typically > 0.92) with relatively little error. The disk rotation angle lag is approximately 80°, which matches to the physical set up of the probes. These results indicate that in this speed range, the disk possess an asymmetric equilibrium that rotates with the disk. This is corroborated by the data shown in Figure 9 in which the actual displacement of the disk measured by both probes is shown versus time for Ω* = 133, 1250, and 2100 r/min. For Ω* = 133 r/min, the disk displacement is a regular pattern of 3 peaks per rotation that repeats every 2π radians. For Ω* = 1250 r/min, the centripetal stiffening of the disk reduces the peak-to-peak displacement of the disk, but the pattern of 3 peaks per rotation persists. Figure 8.
Plot of flexible disk behavior under full gravity loading (Γ = 1250) displaying: (a) correlation coefficient, (b) relative wave speed, and (c) nodal ridges vs. rotation speed. Figure 9.
Displacement measurements for a horizontal flexible disk (Γ = 1250) At Ω* = 133, 1023, and 2212 r/min, respectively.

Between Ω* = 1250 r/min (Ω = 9.1) and Ω* = 1900 r/min (Ω = 13.8), the measurement noise is large and the maximum correlation coefficient is not steady. This is consistent with displacement measurements in which vibration of the disk is as great or greater in magnitude than the nominal steady state displacements of the disk. Since the rotation speed is relatively high, centripetal stiffening of the disk has reduced the measurement signal from the asymmetric equilibrium, if, in fact, such an equilibrium exists. The data only indicates that the signal from the asymmetric equilibrium is not significantly larger than the level of vibration.

For Ω* > 2100 r/min (Ω = 15.3), the error measuring the maximum correlation coefficient reduces significantly and a maximum correlation coefficient between sensor 1 and sensor 2 is similar to those observed for Ω* < 1200. However, for these measurements the angle of rotation corresponding to the correlation lag is approximately 330°, or approximately four times the physical angle between the sensors. This measurement indicates that an asymmetric equilibrium may be present but that it is rotating at one quarter of the rotation speed of the disk.

Figure 10 shows a waterfall plot of the vibration power spectral density as a function of disk rotation speed for the horizontal flexible disk (Γ = 1250). Two lines of peaks emanate from the origin, one at approximately 45° corresponding to a one/revolution signal, the other at approximately 30° corresponding to a twice/revolution signal. These two lines of peaks are consistent with the presence of a rotating, asymmetric equilibrium. However, around Ω* = 1600 r/min, the spectrum changes completely to broad band noise which completely dominates the once and twice/rev signals. This indicates that aerodynamic forces are exciting the disk. Figure 10.
Waterfall contour plot showing the vibration power density spectrum as a function of disk rotation speed for a horizontal flexible disk (Γ = 1250). The lines of peaks at approximately 45° and 30° correspond to the once/rev and twice/rev signals typical of a rotating, asymmetric equilibrium. Above Ω* = 1600 r/min, aerodynamic excitation dominates the signal.

Figures 11 to 13 show the maximum correlation coefficient and corresponding lag, displacement and waterfall plot for a vertically oriented flexible disk (Γ = 0). Qualitatively, the response of the unloaded (vertically oriented) and fully loaded (horizontal orientation) disk are similar. The high correlation, consistent lag, and displacement data in the low speed range clearly indicate the presence of an asymmetric equilibrium even though the disk is unloaded. Such equilibrium is possible if the disk possesses an initial pre-warp. There are, however, significant differences between the loaded and unloaded cases. The correlation factor for the unloaded disk drops below 0.9 at Ω* = 700 while the loaded disk maintains this level until Ω* = 1400. In addition, at high speeds Ω* > 2100 the correlation factor never increases to a significant level averaging a value of 0.53. Figure 11.
Plot of flexible disk behavior under no gravity loading (Γ = 0) displaying: (a) correlation coefficient, (b) relative wave speed, and (c) nodal ridges vs. rotation speed. Figure 12.
Displacement measurements for a vertical flexible disk (Γ = 0) At Ω* = 133, 1023, and 2212, r/min respectively. Figure 13.
Waterfall contour plot showing the vibration power density spectrum as a function of disk rotation speed for a vertical flexible disk (no gravity loading). Unlike the loaded disk shown in Figure 10, the once and twice/rev peaks persist for high rotation speeds and the aerodynamic excitation is confined to frequencies less than the rotation speed.

The waterfall plot for the unloaded disk, Figure 13, provides some insight into the disk behavior. Whereas the loaded disk has no significant vibration frequencies outside of those associated with the asymmetric equilibria below 1600 r/min, the loaded disk develops significant low frequency excitation at 1000 r/min. Further differentiating the two configurations is the absence of higher frequency vibrations. The vibration frequencies excited in the unloaded disk are all confined to frequencies below the rotation speed. This is significantly different from the loaded disk where the initial excitation is broadband extending to almost twice the rotation speed.

From these data the following were concluded (neglecting aerodynamic effects):
1. For low speeds (Ω* < 1200), the flexible disk possesses a disk-based, asymmetric equilibrium configuration due to gravity loading. This equilibrium persists as the disk speed increases. At speeds Ω* > 1200, the disk vibration signal was as strong or stronger than the steady, disk-based equilibrium and no conclusion can be reached regarding the presence of a disk-based equilibrium.
2. The magnitude of the pre-warping in non-rotating flexible disks is on the order of 15 disk thicknesses. Centripetal stiffening of the disk reduces the disk warping by 30% when the disk reaches mid-speed (Ω* = 10).

An attempt was made to measure the effect of variable gravitational loading on the equilibrium configuration of the flexible disk. The load was varied by changing the inclination of the setup between horizontal (full gravitational load) and vertical (no gravitational load). No significant effect was found.

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: While spectral collocation proved to be an effective method for locating asymmetric equilibria, it exhibited the same numerical difficulties that plagued other methods. Stability boundaries were not smooth even for highly refined grids.

In order to identify equilibria a brute-force method was implemented, systematically varying the initial solution guess until a solution was found, and restricting the search to solutions with quadrilateral symmetry. Using this method, three asymmetric equilibria were located in addition to the axisymmetric solution previously identified, but a stable solution at each rotation speed was not found. The asymmetric solutions that were found were characterized as bifurcations of the axisymmetric solution with one, two or three nodal ridges.

An initial disk curvature of the form w~=ar2cos2θ was found to have a significant effect at low speeds with only a marginal effect at high speeds for flexible rotating disks. A small pre-warp (a = 0.5, a = −0.5) was found to have little effect but larger pre-warps were found to alter the buckling load by as much as an order of magnitude. Centripetal stiffening was able to combat the effects of pre-warp. At high speeds, Ω > 15 all the results for all warping mirrored those for the unwarped disk.

Finally the behavior of a flexible disk as it is rotated at different speeds was investigated to see if the equilibrium observed in the stationary disk persist. Using two optical sensors it was determined that a disk-based equilibrium configuration persists on the flexible disk through low to medium speeds. At medium to high speeds the presence of excessive excitations prevented any further conclusions. These excitations, most likely caused by aerodynamic forces, did appear to generate an equilibrium solution that traveled at approximately one quarter of the disk rotation speed.

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p: Spectral collation was used to determine equilibria for a thin rotating disk under uniform (gravity) loading. Three asymmetric equilibria were found and their stability determined as a function of rotation speed and load. A relatively large number of degrees of freedom (144) were needed to identify and discard false equilibria. The equilibria reported here are thought to be true solutions.
Stability curves as a function of rotation speed and loading were computed for perfect disks, disks rotating with a small eccentricity, and for disk possessing an initial pre-warp.

Apart from brute force, no method was able to reliably find asymmetric equilibria. Even when equilibrium was found, it was difficult to track this equilibrium through small changes in load and rotation speed. In one case, the solution seemed to disappear about a certain load. For large prewarp, the stability curves do not vary in a smooth manner. These numerical difficulties are consistent with previous studies.

Experimental results corroborated the presence of a rotating, asymmetric equilibrium for low speeds. At higher speeds, aerodynamically excited vibration made it impossible to identify steady equilibria. However, the nature of the aerodynamic excitation and its onset were dramatically affected by the presence of uniform loading on the disk. In addition, at high rotation speeds, the disk appears to have a steady equilibrium rotation at one quarter of the rotation speed of the disk.

The numerical results suggest that pre-warp can lend themselves to increases in the stability margin of spinning disks. Increases in stability margin can lead to higher operation speeds. Higher operation speeds are generally desirable in disk drive and saw applications, but are limited by instabilities in the disk. It should be noted, however, that there is a limited class of disks that allow for initial deformations suggested in this study.

sec.title: Funding
sec.p: This research received no specific grant from any funding agency in the public, commercial, or not-for-profit sectors.
